articles.headline: How to Figure Out if You Can Actually Afford That New Home
articles.snippet: It’s tempting to jump into the home-buying frenzy. But with prices up and mortgage rates surging, make sure you do the math first.
articles.abstract: It’s tempting to jump into the home-buying frenzy. But with prices up and mortgage rates surging, make sure you do the math first.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: How Technocrats Triumphed at Apple
articles.snippet: The man who helped give the world candy-colored computers eventually walked out the door. What does that mean for the company’s next big thing?
articles.abstract: The man who helped give the world candy-colored computers eventually walked out the door. What does that mean for the company’s next big thing?
articles.lead_paragraph: After two years of development, thousands of engineering hours and countless days agonizing over the suppleness of leather and strength of gold for Apple’s bold new product, the company’s design chief, Jony Ive, was thrust into a high-stakes debate over the most primitive concern: a tent.

articles.headline: Inside China’s Zero-Covid Fortress, Xi Admits No Doubts
articles.snippet: As the lockdown of Shanghai and outbreaks in Beijing and elsewhere batter the economy, China’s leader keeps a distance from the politically charged issue.
articles.abstract: As the lockdown of Shanghai and outbreaks in Beijing and elsewhere batter the economy, China’s leader keeps a distance from the politically charged issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, waved at crowds of giddily cheering students. He held meetings with Olympic Games officials, economic policymakers and European leaders. He toured a tropical island.

articles.headline: Pelosi Visit to Ukraine Signals Growing U.S. Resolve Against Russia
articles.snippet: In Mariupol, the scene of intense fighting, civilians who had taken refuge at a steel plant were at least able to begin evacuating.
articles.abstract: In Mariupol, the scene of intense fighting, civilians who had taken refuge at a steel plant were at least able to begin evacuating.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — House Speaker Nancy Pelosi traveled to Ukraine’s capital over the weekend, leading the second senior American delegation to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky in a week and declare support for his country’s fight to beat back the Russian invasion.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger, Jane Arraf and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Russian Tycoon Criticized Putin’s War. Retribution Was Swift.
articles.snippet: Oleg Tinkov spoke out against his country’s war in Ukraine. Now he is in hiding. In an exclusive interview he said, “I don’t believe in Russia’s future’’ under Vladimir Putin.
articles.abstract: Oleg Tinkov spoke out against his country’s war in Ukraine. Now he is in hiding. In an exclusive interview he said, “I don’t believe in Russia’s future’’ under Vladimir Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oleg Y. Tinkov was worth more than $9 billion in November, renowned as one of Russia’s few self-made business tycoons after building his fortune outside the energy and minerals industries that were the playgrounds of Russian kleptocracy.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Another Firing Among Google’s A.I. Brain Trust, and More Discord
articles.snippet: The researchers are considered a key to the company’s future. But they have had a hard time shaking infighting and controversy over a variety of issues.
articles.abstract: The researchers are considered a key to the company’s future. But they have had a hard time shaking infighting and controversy over a variety of issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than two years after Google dismissed two researchers who criticized the biases built into artificial intelligence systems, the company has fired a researcher who questioned a paper it published on the abilities of a specialized type of artificial intelligence used in making computer chips.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cade Metz

articles.headline: They Fell Deeply in Love in Bucha. One Russian Bullet Ended It All.
articles.snippet: Over nearly two decades, Iryna Abramova and her husband, Oleh, built a life of love and happiness. Now, she says, she wishes the Russian soldiers had shot her, too.
articles.abstract: Over nearly two decades, Iryna Abramova and her husband, Oleh, built a life of love and happiness. Now, she says, she wishes the Russian soldiers had shot her, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — She called him Sunshine. He called her Kitty.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Daniel Berehulak
